Ray Kiddy wrote:
> 
> On Feb 13, 2004, at 2:25 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> 
>  > Ray Kiddy wrote:
>  >  >
>  >  > Sorry if this is an obvious question.
>  >  >
>  >  > I want to set a test to be verbose and then, sometimes, I want to
>  > see
>  >  > output from my assert methods whether they pass or fail. Say that I
>  >  > want to make sure all the tests are actually getting called.
>  >
>  >  Why wouldn't your tests be executed? Are you worried that you are
>  >  building test suites incorrectly or that the test runners are broken?
>  > Or
>  >  is it something else?
> 
> There are all sorts of reasons that things might not get executed. For
> one thing, I am not using the TestRunner functionality. It is not,
> actually, a requirement when using junit.

You're writing your own test runner? I see. In that case, just implement 
TestListener /or/ use the JUnit-addons test runner, which provides an 
open test listener architecture, making it very easy to track the 
progress of each test.

> But, also, if I am going to set up something that is going to run
> automatically for some period of time, then I will carefully check to
> confirm that it is doing exactly what I think it is doing, at least
> once.

I understand that, but, for example, if I run the Swing-based test 
runner, I can watch the tests make progress. Once I'm satisfied that 
nothing's obviously broken, I'm pretty confident in the test runners. 
The text-based one, for example, prints a dot for each test. If I don't 
see "E" or "F", then that test must have passed.

> It seems easy enough to add a method in junit that takes an
> OutputStream and writes verbose output to that stream.

No need to add a method in JUnit: just implement the TestListener 
interface. Since you're writing your own test runner, you'll have to do 
that, anyway.

> This is sort of on general principals. If you are writing a framework,
> there needs to be a way to run the framework for maximum transparency,
> as well as a way to run them most efficiently.

That's an interesting statement. I don't mean to contradict you, but if 
that were such a general principal, then I'd think someone else would 
have brought that up sometime between 2000 and now.

<snip />
> Then I will write up something and submit it to the sourceforge team.

Good luck. I'll say this, though: if you would say more about what 
specifically you're trying to achieve and why the current framework 
doesn't do it, we might be able to suggest a solution that doesn't 
require more code.
